column10: Pay;Dissatisfied with Job;Dissatisfied with Supervisor;
column20: Fire Jill
column21: Jill does not take responsibility and own up to her mistakes and I was being discriminated against by Jill she made the work environment vey hostile for me it was pointless to tell Perry anything because he went along with whatever she said rumor was they were sleeping together not my business not the leadership I want to work under you canï¿½t accomplish anything with them both agreeing against you anyway I feel all Jill was focusing on was the budget basically after speaking with her and Perry about the 90 day evaluation that I was promised a fifty cent raise by Jason whom was and is no loner there I did and was doing everything right after me asking two months still after my ninety days Jill through up an evaluation and lied on it with Perry present there I should not have signed it because I didnï¿½t agree with it but I was afraid I would be terminated because Jill didnï¿½t like me and was making my work environment hostile for me I had been lied to by this company from the start of my employment

column10: Full time position ;
Full time position ;
Dissatisfied with Job;Dissatisfied with Supervisor;
column12: The intake referral process pretty much was dumped on me without even asking me if this is something Iï¿½d like to do. I was given 6 1/2 days of training to a very chaotic and unorganized intake referral system. When I would asked questions to my supervisor pertaining to the intake referral process she would say thatï¿½s not important right now will address that later. Well to me, it was very important at that moment. I was trying to learn the system and other coworkers told me the intake referral process is a beast. Indeed it was. I shouldï¿½ve been able to have ample time to adjust to all the ins and outs of this new role. The amount of notes I took, couldnï¿½t compare to the one on one I needed in making this successful for me otherwise I would still be there.
column15: As I said, 6 1/2 days of training was not enough time to learn what I needed to know. Every situation was different on just about every referral. Even the seasoned intake referral people constantly made mistakes. One person would say to do it this way and other person would say do it that way. There was never any consistency.
column18: No comment
column20: No comment
column21: I gave 100% to this company. Iï¿½ve worked overtime and worked through lunch knowing there wouldnï¿½t be any compensation. I also cleaned the office so they didnï¿½t have to hire an outside company. Yes I cleaned the toilet, swept and mopped, emptied trash cans and took out the trash to the dumpster. I absolutely loved my job before the new role came into place. As I look back, I feel that I wasnï¿½t appreciated for my efforts. I was always on time and never late for work. And out of the year and a half I worked, I only called in sick twice, one being August 22, 2025.I lost all my PTO because I called in sick on August 22 and by doing so it meant that I had to work Thursday, August 28 or I would lose my PTO. Itï¿½s unfortunate that my husband and I already had a trip planned for Thursday and Friday August 28th and 29th. This trip could not be rearranged.This trip had already been approved for PTO months ago by my supervisor.

column10: Personal/Family Reasons;
column12: From the start of my time with Magnolia Hospice, my direct supervisor was difficult to communicate with. Not very organized or timely, rather erratic. She was also difficult to get direct answers from and I looked to other employees and colleagues for direction and support, especially in my first few months.
column15: My executive director, the back office clinical staff, and my seasoned peers provided great support during my time with Magnolia Hospice. The 4 stars is a reflection of the limited level of support from my direct supervisor. It was almost as if she did not want me to succeed.
column18: Local management, with the exception of my supervisor, was great. I did not communicate often with corporate management, but when I did, it was timely, professional, helpful and appreciated.
column20: Promoting within an organization is great, but make sure the people you promote have the skill set and temperament for the role. Successful sales people do not always translate to successful managers.
column21: I am grateful for my time with Magnolia Hospice. In my 6 months of employment, I met a lot of great people and overall was quite happy with my role. I am 6 months pregnant and the physical demands of driving that my role requires ultimately led me to resign sooner than I would have liked.

column10: Pay;Dissatisfied with Job;Dissatisfied with Supervisor;Opportuitny For Growth;- the two weeks I was in training Jessica and Priscilla had been doing my patients visits at assisted living before I get to work, then telling me to do the charting and let the time go for 30 mins when I get there even though I didnt see the patient  - Monday, Sept. 8th Jessica didnt use gloves when getting Lambaren up for shower and she was covered in urine  - Jessica and Priscilla start patient visits at least 5 minutes before they arrive at patient home  - Jessica and Faline have been rude and talking about me even in front of other people, I was told about one time from a RN in a facility - Faline does not work as a team with me no matter how hard I try, even ignores me when I try to have a conversation  - Jessica and Faline will take my patients to bathe them while telling me to just make the bed or grab clothes instead of teaching me and letting me learn my patients  - Dont have full time hours  - My pay isnt enough for my bills  - Hospice isnt what I expected it to be ;
column12: When I would message my supervisor about certain topics she wouldnï¿½t answer my message but it I text again about a patient she would answer that while still ignoring my other messages.
column15: There was only 1 Aide (Priscilla) that encouraged me and let me do hands on practices so I could learn how to do my job effectively.
column18: Some people were super helpful, but others were not.
column20: Encourage better team work, make sure things that are talked about in meetings actually happen and make it out of the meeting, and make sure supervisors jobs are done effectively.
column21: I do not have any other information.

column10: Low Patient workload & staff coordinator refused to increase;
column12: Remarkable Hospice ranks #3 out of the top 5 good hospice agencies in the DFW metroplex. Poor communication was the biggest issue with the staff coordinator & supervisor. There were concerns regarding the facilities' caregivers not wanting to abide by the patients' care plans from the agency. The DON (Ricki Dickey) nor the staff coordinator, (Wendi Kissane) tried to reiterate the safety guidelines, regarding the transferring of the patients who were considered total care/Hoyer level. That was the only issue that I had with this agency.
column15: I felt that every time I voiced my concerns, the staff brushed it off and saw me as a problem & replaced me with someone else.
column18: I never got the chance to deal with corporate, but management at the local office in Plano needs to handle situations, so that their caregivers can provide better care for the patients.
column20: Management should work better to help their caregivers provide better care for the patients. They shouldn't be so quick to lessen the workload or replace a caregiver, whenever they express a concern regarding the lack of assistance or other problems from facilities' caregivers.

column10: Dissatisfied with Job;Dissatisfied with Supervisor;Personal/Family Reasons;
column12: Summer is good with 1 on 1 communication. However the way she conducts herself in the office shows favoritism towards one nurse.  This has been brought to her attention before without resolution. She allows this nurse to act as a boss in certain circumstances and doesn't stop her.
column15: Summer did not reach out personally when my mom was sick until it affected my job. Then I was reprimanded. My mental health was failing and it wasnt noticed.
column18:
3 stars for local
5 stars for corporate
column20: Stop playing favorites.  Yes, it's a business but we are people too. Stop allowing people to manipulate and stop manipulating. Work the field like you used to when we got super busy. Setting another branch up for success won't work if your home branch is crumbling.
column21: Most clinical staff is unhappy and looking for other jobs. Be ready. And know why we all left.

column10: Dissatisfied with Job;Dissatisfied with Supervisor;Personal/Family Reasons;
column12: Summer is good with 1 on 1 communication. However the way she conducts herself in the office shows favoritism towards one nurse.  This has been brought to her attention before without resolution. She allows this nurse to act as a boss in certain circumstances and doesn't stop her.
column15: Summer did not reach out personally when my mom was sick until it affected my job. Then I was reprimanded. My mental health was failing and it wasnt noticed.

Dissatisfied with Supervisor;Personal/Family Reasons;
column12: Over the past several months, communication within the office has significantly declined. While initial interactions were clear and constructive, more recent exchanges have been inconsistent and confusing. For example, I was given specific instructions by the director on how to complete certain tasks, only to be questioned days later about why I followed those very instructions.
column15:
Several concerns were brought forward regarding the conduct of the male marketer, whose repeated disruptive behavior negatively impacted the office environment. This included intentionally startling colleagues for amusement, which I found inappropriate and unsettling. After expressing my discomfort, I was advised to address the issue directly with him. I followed through on that guidance; however, the behavior continued.

In addition, I reported multiple instances where he appeared to foster unnecessary interpersonal conflict and drama within the team. Despite these concerns being communicated clearly and in good faith, no meaningful action was taken to address the situation. As evidenced by the fact that the behavior persisted.
column18:
From a corporate perspective, I have no major concerns and truly valued the opportunity to serve patients and families in alignment with the hospice mission. However, the local office environment became increasingly unprofessional and toxic, negatively affecting morale and team dynamics. After distancing myself from a close-knit social group, I experienced unequal work distribution and became the subject of workplace discussions that contributed to a hostile and exclusionary atmosphere.

I also observed ongoing gossip and disparaging remarks from leadership following employee resignations, which undermined professionalism and respect. These patterns are inconsistent with the organization’s values of dignity and collaboration. I share this feedback in hopes of encouraging reflection and positive change, while also expressing concern about potential retaliation impacting future opportunities.
column20:
I believe this team has the potential to be exceptionally strong and effective with the right support and oversight. A surprise visit and direct observation by corporate leadership could offer valuable insight into the current dynamics and help identify areas for improvement that may not be visible from a distance.

Operationally, it would be highly beneficial to restructure the RN Case Manager coverage. Specifically, having three dedicated RNCMs supported by a fourth RNCM focused on admissions and transitional patient pickups would significantly enhance workflow efficiency. This model would allow the primary RNCMs to maintain continuity of care while ensuring timely onboarding of new patients.

Additionally, expanding to four nurses would make the on-call schedule more sustainable. As it stands, call responsibilities can be burdensome and impact both morale and patient care. A more balanced distribution would alleviate strain and promote a healthier work environment for the clinical team.
column21:
I strongly encourage that the branch be managed with a business-minded approach rather than one driven by personal relationships. Professional boundaries and accountability are essential to fostering a culture of respect, equity, and high-quality care. When team dynamics are influenced by social alliances, it undermines morale, disrupts workflow, and compromises the integrity of patient care.

It is imperative that all team members, especially nurses, remain open to questions, collaborative dialogue, and shared problem-solving. The tendency to respond defensively with statements such as ï¿½I put it in my documentationï¿½ discourages meaningful communication and weakens interdisciplinary support. None of us are immune to occasional oversights, and a healthy team culture should prioritize mutual support and continuous improvement over fault-finding and gossip.

Additionally, staffing levels must be addressed proactively. Even when census is lower, maintaining adequate coverage with nurses and CNAs is critical to reducing burnout, improving retention, and ensuring that documentation and care responsibilities can be completed during regular business hours. When staff are consistently forced to document after hours due to workload constraints, it signals a systemic issue that deserves immediate attention. Same applies when the CNAs not on call are working well past 5pm. 

Investing in a more balanced, professional, and collaborative environment will not only improve team cohesion but also elevate the standard of care we provide to patients and families.

Itï¿½s essential that marketers maintain appropriate boundaries when engaging in discussions related to clinical care, whether with patients, families, facilities, or colleagues. While one marketer consistently demonstrates respect for these limits, another has shown a pattern of deflecting responsibility and assigning blame when outcomes are not favorable. This behavior undermines team cohesion and can compromise trust across disciplines.

Additionally, decisions that impact staff scheduling, such as assigning a CNA to visit a facility five times per week in addition to their existing caseload, should be made in collaboration. The CNA and RNCM at the Sweetwater branch were informed of this change without prior consultation, which raises concerns about feasibility, workload, and respect for staff input.

Further, after the RNCM was given approval by Summer to speak with Sweetwater Healthcare regarding a potential reduction in daily visits (particularly given that two patients frequently refuse care), it was discovered that Zach had already spoken with Debbie, the Director of Nursing. Based on that conversation, the directive was that the CNA must continue to offer daily visits, even if they are consistently declined. If declined they could then be canceled. This decision was communicated without involving the RNCM, who should have been the one to initiate that discussion with facility nursing staff.

This is yet another example of the importance of role clarity. Clinical decisions, especially those involving visit frequency, patient engagement, and care coordination, should be led by licensed clinicians. When non-clinical staff make unilateral decisions or bypass appropriate channels, it not only disrupts workflow but also diminishes the integrity of patient-centered care.

column10: Dissatisfied with Supervisor;
column12: At the beginning, Summer Kelley's communication was impressive, but over the past several months, the office communication has dropped off. She would communicate schedule changes with us collaboratively as a team, but now it's become more of a 'you're being told' approach rather than a team-based one.
column15: I was inadequately informed by Summer and Zach that I would be required to attend a facility in Sweetwater, 40 miles away, five days a week to see four patients, in addition to my existing six patients. This excessive scheduling, imposed by Summer and Zach, compromised the quality of care I could provide, with no additional support. My workdays were extended to 9-11 hours, with daily travel of 100 miles. I addressed these concerns with Summer on multiple occasions, only to be told that the facility arrangement was made to secure a single patient. she failed to support her team for success.
column18: From a corporate perspective, I appreciate the opportunity to have been part of the company for the past two years. I have learned and grown significantly during my tenure. Conversely, I have concerns regarding leadership style. A leader should facilitate team success, mitigate burnout, and demonstrate appreciation. They should focus on achieving goals, rather than discussing personal matters during meetings. Effective leaders listen to concerns and address problems to prevent burnout. Unfortunately, the supervisor's approach has been inconsistent with these principles, permitting unprofessional behavior, including smoking, cursing, and inappropriate sexual conversations, This has been brought to her attention multiple times it continues to happen at the branch.
column20: With the right leadership in place, I firmly believe that this team has the potential to be extremely strong and accomplish great things.
column21: I strongly recommend that corporate leadership consider making a surprise visit to address these complaints before further employee losses occur
